newsitem.title: USA: Ore. says still open to Enron merger deal.
newsitem.headline: Ore. says still open to Enron merger deal.

text.p: The staff of Oregon Public Utility Commission (OPUC), which will release Friday a final report on the proposed merger of Enron Corp and Portland General Electric Co, remains open to a merger settlement, but but only on its own terms.
"If we get a phone call from Enron and they are willing to take our last offer, we will call the parties together and make a deal," OPUC spokesman Mike Allegre said this week.
On Enron's side, however, nothing new is expected until after the staff releases the report, Enron spokesman Gary Foster said Thursday.
The staff said last month the final report would call for disapproval of the deal.
Earlier merger settlement talks faltered over the issue of a rate cut for Oregon electricity customers.
The OPUC staff said it will not recommend approval of the merger without a rate reduction of $160 million, compared with Enron's last offer of $61 million.
"We are looking at customer compensation (money owed to ratepayers to offset harm from the merger) and benefits (additional revenues associated with the merger)," explained Allegre.
Without a merger, nothing will change for Oregon ratepayers, who would get more long-term benefits if the deal does not go through, he said.
But he emphasized that the "door is still open" for a settlement.
The Oregon commission is scheduled to make final decision on the merger on June 4.
